items.title: Two killed by US strike on alleged drug-trafficking boat in Pacific Ocean
items.standfirst: A strike launched by the US military killed two people on an alleged drug-trafficking vessel in the Pacific Ocean, US Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth said on Wednesday. The latest strike marks an expansion of what US President Donald Trump described as an "armed conflict" with South America's drug cartels that has, until now, targeted vessels in the Caribbean.
items.content: A strike launched by the US military killed two people on an alleged drug-trafficking vessel in the Pacific Ocean, US Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth said on Wednesday. The latest strike marks an expansion of what US President Donald Trump described as an "armed conflict" with South America's drug cartels that has, until now, targeted vessels in the Caribbean.

items.title: Expert says Putin doesn't respond to pressure as Trump announces new sanctions
items.standfirst: The Trump administration is trying to pressure Russia into a ceasefire, announcing new sanctions Wednesday against major Russian oil companies. Nina Khrushcheva, professor of international affairs at the New School and the great-granddaughter of former Soviet Prime Minister Nikita Khrushchev, joins "The Daily Report" to discuss.
items.content: The Trump administration is trying to pressure Russia into a ceasefire, announcing new sanctions Wednesday against major Russian oil companies. Nina Khrushcheva, professor of international affairs at the New School and the great-granddaughter of former Soviet Prime Minister Nikita Khrushchev, joins "The Daily Report" to discuss.

items.standfirst: Trump administration hardens stance against the Kremlin day after cancelling a planned summit with Russian leaderThe US has sanctioned Rosneft and Lukoil, Russia’s two largest oil companies, as the Trump administration increased pressure on the Kremlin to negotiate an end to its war against Ukraine.The sanctions were the first against Russia since Donald Trump returned to the White House in January, and were targeted to cut key revenues from oil sales that finance the Russian war machine. Continue reading...

items.title: U.S. sanctions Russia's two largest oil companies
items.standfirst: The Treasury Department announced new sanctions targeting Russia’s oil sector Wednesday, the day after President Donald Trump confirmed that a planned meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin to discuss Russia's war with Ukraine was off. “Now is the time to stop the killing and for an immediate ceasefire,” Secretary of the Treasury Scott Bessent said in a statement.
items.content: The Treasury Department announced new sanctions targeting Russia’s oil sector Wednesday, the day after President Donald Trump confirmed that a planned meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin to discuss Russia's war with Ukraine was off. “Now is the time to stop the killing and for an immediate ceasefire,” Secretary of the Treasury Scott Bessent said in a statement.

items.title: White House announces new sanctions on Russian oil companies

items.content: The White House announced new sanctions on Russia targeting the country's two largest oil companies. NBC News’ Gabe Gutierrez details the significance of the sanctions.

items.title: Putin wasn't 'honest' with Trump, treasury chief says as US imposes massive sanctions
items.standfirst: The United States is to impose one of its largest-ever sanctions packages against Russia because Vladimir Putin was not "honest" in talks with Donald Trump, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Wednesday. "President Putin has not come to the table in an honest and forthright manner, as we'd hoped," Bessent told Fox Business, adding that Trump was "disappointed at where we are in these talks." FRANCE 24's Fraser Jackson reports from Washington.
items.content: The United States is to impose one of its largest-ever sanctions packages against Russia because Vladimir Putin was not "honest" in talks with Donald Trump, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Wednesday. "President Putin has not come to the table in an honest and forthright manner, as we'd hoped," Bessent told Fox Business, adding that Trump was "disappointed at where we are in these talks." FRANCE 24's Fraser Jackson reports from Washington.

clusters.title: France's Heist of the Century

items.title: France's Heist of the Century
items.standfirst: The Louvre reopening for the first time since Sunday’s heist of the century. We’ll follow leads in a daylight robbery now estimated at 88 million euros and check security at the world’s most visited museum.
items.content: The Louvre reopening for the first time since Sunday’s heist of the century. We’ll follow leads in a daylight robbery now estimated at 88 million euros and check security at the world’s most visited museum.

items.title: Louvre reopens after $102M crown jewel heist

items.content: The Louvre Museum re-opened three days after a daring daytime heist of eight pieces of France’s crown jewels.

items.content: The famous Paris museum reopened on Wednesday, three days after millions of euros worth of jewellery stolen in broad daylight.

items.content: PARIS — The Louvre reopened Wednesday morning for the first time since the brazen heist of France's crown jewels

ai_summary: The Louvre Museum reopened after a daytime heist of crown jewels.

The museum reopened three days after the daring robbery.
Thieves remain at large following the heist.

clusters.title: Trump plans to demolish White House's entire East Wing for ballroom as cost jumps to $300 million
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump to Demolish Entire East Wing to Build White House Ballroom

items.title: Trump plans to demolish White House's entire East Wing for ballroom as cost jumps to $300 million
items.standfirst: Senior White House officials have confirmed to CBS News that the entire East Wing will be demolished to make way for the new ballroom championed by President Trump. The estimated cost has also increased to $300 million. Deepa Shivram, White House correspondent for NPR, and Eleanor Mueller, Congress reporter for Semafor, join "The Takeout" to discuss.
items.content: Senior White House officials have confirmed to CBS News that the entire East Wing will be demolished to make way for the new ballroom championed by President Trump. The estimated cost has also increased to $300 million. Deepa Shivram, White House correspondent for NPR, and Eleanor Mueller, Congress reporter for Semafor, join "The Takeout" to discuss.

items.title: White House plans to demolish entire East Wing as ballroom cost hits $300 million
items.standfirst: The Trump administration is planning to demolish the entirety of the White House's East Wing as early as this weekend, two senior administration officials said, part of a ballroom project championed by President Trump.
items.content: The Trump administration is planning to demolish the entirety of the White House's East Wing as early as this weekend, two senior administration officials said, part of a ballroom project championed by President Trump.

items.title: Trump says 'existing structure' of White House East Wing to be torn down
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump previously said that his ballroom addition would not "interfere with the current building".
items.content: US President Donald Trump previously said that his ballroom addition would not "interfere with the current building".

items.title: Trump to Demolish Entire East Wing to Build White House Ballroom
White House Demolition Update: Entire East Wing to Be Torn Down by Weekend

items.content: The move contradicts Trump’s pledge that construction of the long-discussed ballroom would not affect the East Wing structure.

items.content: Heavy machinery tears down a section of the East Wing of the White House as construction begins on President Donald Trump's planned ballroom, in Washington, DC, on October 22, 2025.

items.title: Ballroom construction pauses White House tours, but likely to resume soon
items.standfirst: Demolition of parts of the East Wing of the White House and construction of the new ballroom have meant tours have been suspended for about two months.
items.content: Demolition of parts of the East Wing of the White House and construction of the new ballroom have meant tours have been suspended for about two months.

ai_summary: The White House plans to demolish the entire East Wing.

The project contradicts Trump's previous statements.
The estimated cost of the project has increased to $300 million.
Tours of the White House have been suspended for about two months.

items.standfirst: School joins University of Pennsylvania, Columbia and Brown in bowing to White House to restore fundingThe University of Virginia (UVA) has become the latest institution to agree to the Trump administration’s demands concerning discrimination in admissions and hiring following significant pressure from the justice department.The deal, which the department announced on Wednesday, comes after the president of the esteemed public university resigned in June to resolve a justice department investigation into UVA’s diversity, equity and inclusion policies. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Louvre director admits 'insufficient' camera coverage after heist
clusters.neutral_headline: Louvre director admits 'insufficient' security after heist

items.title: Louvre director admits 'insufficient' camera coverage after heist
items.standfirst: The director of the Louvre on Wednesday admitted to inadequate camera surveillance of the museum's outside walls, three days after thieves robbed it of prize jewels in a brazen daytime heist. But Laurence des Cars said that a diamond- and emerald-studded crown that the burglars damaged and dropped as they fled on Sunday could be restored. FRANCE 24's Yinka Oyetade reports.
items.content: The director of the Louvre on Wednesday admitted to inadequate camera surveillance of the museum's outside walls, three days after thieves robbed it of prize jewels in a brazen daytime heist. But Laurence des Cars said that a diamond- and emerald-studded crown that the burglars damaged and dropped as they fled on Sunday could be restored. FRANCE 24's Yinka Oyetade reports.

items.title: No camera covered Louvre wall where jewel thieves broke in, director says
items.standfirst: Laurence des Cars said there was only one camera pointing on the gallery which was robbed.
items.content: Laurence des Cars said there was only one camera pointing on the gallery which was robbed.

items.title: Louvre director acknowledges ‘terrible failure’ after €88m jewel heist
items.standfirst: Laurence des Cars questioned by senators about daring daytime break-in at Paris museumThe director of the Louvre museum in Paris has acknowledged a “terrible failure” days after thieves took seven minutes to break in via a window and steal jewels worth €88m, admitting there was “highly insufficient” security camera coverage of the outside walls of the vast building.Senators questioned Laurence des Cars about the spectacular heist in which four men used a truck with extendable ladder and furniture hoist to access a balcony, cut through a window and steal jewels from the ornate Apollo gallery during opening hours. Continue reading...
items.content: Laurence des Cars questioned by senators about daring daytime break-in at Paris museumThe director of the Louvre museum in Paris has acknowledged a “terrible failure” days after thieves took seven minutes to break in via a window and steal jewels worth €88m, admitting there was “highly insufficient” security camera coverage of the outside walls of the vast building.Senators questioned Laurence des Cars about the spectacular heist in which four men used a truck with extendable ladder and furniture hoist to access a balcony, cut through a window and steal jewels from the ornate Apollo gallery during opening hours. Continue reading...

items.title: Louvre director admits 'insufficient' security and says she offered to resign after jewel heist
items.standfirst: The director of the Louvre on Wednesday told the French Senate there was "insufficient" security camera coverage at the instutution and that she had offered her resignation – which was refused by France's culture minister – after an audacious heist on Sunday saw thieves break into the museum and steal €88 million worth of jewels.
items.content: The director of the Louvre on Wednesday told the French Senate there was "insufficient" security camera coverage at the instutution and that she had offered her resignation – which was refused by France's culture minister – after an audacious heist on Sunday saw thieves break into the museum and steal €88 million worth of jewels.

ai_summary: The Louvre director admitted to inadequate camera coverage.
The director stated there was only one camera on the gallery.
The heist involved the theft of jewels worth €88 million.
The director acknowledged a "terrible failure" in security.
The director offered her resignation, which was refused.

clusters.title: ICJ orders Israel to allow aid into Gaza and says restrictions breached international obligations
clusters.neutral_headline: ICJ orders Israel to allow aid into Gaza

items.title: ICJ orders Israel to allow aid into Gaza and says restrictions breached international obligations
items.standfirst: UN’s top court also finds Israel failed to justify blocking Unrwa and other relief agenciesIsrael must allow aid into Gaza, and its restrictions on doing so over the past two years have put it in breach of its obligations, the UN’s top court has found.The stinging advisory opinion by the International Court of Justice in The Hague also found that Israel had a duty not to impede the supply of aid by UN organisations including the beleaguered UN Palestinian relief agency Unrwa, which has been in effect banned from the territory since January. Continue reading...
items.content: UN’s top court also finds Israel failed to justify blocking Unrwa and other relief agenciesIsrael must allow aid into Gaza, and its restrictions on doing so over the past two years have put it in breach of its obligations, the UN’s top court has found.The stinging advisory opinion by the International Court of Justice in The Hague also found that Israel had a duty not to impede the supply of aid by UN organisations including the beleaguered UN Palestinian relief agency Unrwa, which has been in effect banned from the territory since January. Continue reading...

items.title: UN's top court says Israel obliged to allow UN aid into Gaza
items.standfirst: The court also says Israel has not substantiated its allegations against the UN agency for Palestinian refugees.
items.content: The court also says Israel has not substantiated its allegations against the UN agency for Palestinian refugees.

items.title: After ICJ ruling, can UN relief agency UNRWA resume full Gaza operations?
items.standfirst: ICJ states Israel must allow aid into Gaza, ensuring food, water, medicine, and shelter for the Palestinian population.
items.content: ICJ states Israel must allow aid into Gaza, ensuring food, water, medicine, and shelter for the Palestinian population.

items.title: ICJ says Israel must allow aid into blockaded Gaza, provide ‘basic needs’
items.standfirst: In its advisory opinion, the UN's top court says Israel must support UN institutions, including UNRWA, with aid efforts.
items.content: In its advisory opinion, the UN's top court says Israel must support UN institutions, including UNRWA, with aid efforts.

ai_summary: The ICJ ordered Israel to allow aid into Gaza.
The court found Israel's restrictions breached obligations.
The court found Israel failed to justify blocking UNRWA.
The court said Israel must support UN institutions with aid.
The ruling is an advisory opinion by the ICJ.

clusters.title: Nebraska Farmers Union president on planned Trump aid: Helpful, but not adequate

items.title: Nebraska Farmers Union president on planned Trump aid: Helpful, but not adequate
items.standfirst: Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins says the Trump administration will distribute more than $3 billion in aid for farmers as the government shutdown continues. The agriculture department has not yet said which types of farmers would receive aid. John Hansen, Nebraska Farmers Union President, joins "The Daily Report" to discuss.
items.content: Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins says the Trump administration will distribute more than $3 billion in aid for farmers as the government shutdown continues. items.title: Democrats call on Rubio to help secure release of Palestinian-American teen held in Israeli prison
items.standfirst: Group of 27 Congress members wrote to Marco Rubio to call for ‘swift release’ of 16-year-old Mohammed IbrahimUS politics live – latest updatesMore than two dozen Democratic lawmakers have written to the secretary of state, Marco Rubio, and the US ambassador to Israel urging them to help secure the release of Mohammed Ibrahim, a 16-year-old Palestinian-American citizen who has been held in Israeli military detention for nearly eight months.Ibrahim, a dual Palestinian-American teenager from Florida, was arrested in a raid on his family’s West Bank home in February when he was 15 years old. Israeli forces allegedly blindfolded and handcuffed the boy at 3am, according to the letter led by senators Chris Van Hollen and Jeff Merkley and representatives Kathy Castor and Maxwell Frost. Continue reading...
items.content: Group of 27 Congress members wrote to Marco Rubio to call for ‘swift release’ of 16-year-old Mohammed IbrahimUS politics live – latest updatesMore than two dozen Democratic lawmakers have written to the secretary of state, Marco Rubio, and the US ambassador to Israel urging them to help secure the release of Mohammed Ibrahim, a 16-year-old Palestinian-American citizen who has been held in Israeli military detention for nearly eight months.Ibrahim, a dual Palestinian-American teenager from Florida, was arrested in a raid on his family’s West Bank home in February when he was 15 years old. Israeli forces allegedly blindfolded and handcuffed the boy at 3am, according to the letter led by senators Chris Van Hollen and Jeff Merkley and representatives Kathy Castor and Maxwell Frost. Continue reading...
